text:

The problem is, iCML doesn’t sync play-counts across devices.

text:
3 stars can play every three months. 4 stars can play every month. 5 stars can play every week.  I also use keywords in the Comments field for speciality playlists, but now I'm getting too nerdy and you don’t really need to know about those. ;) 

Onward...
author: VodkaPundit

text: Anyway, with iTunes I found a way to apply those rotation rules to my own music, using your Smart Playlists. The difference is, instead of determining rotation by how old a song is, my rotation goes by how many stars a song has.
author: VodkaPundit

text: We DJs learned to hate those songs in hot rotation. But so long as we chose music according to the rotation rules, we were free to program each hour of music as we saw fit.  It’s been a long time since management allowed jox that much discretion, but that’s another story.
author: VodkaPundit

text: We had a smaller library of songs that were a year old or less, and could play every week. Then there were the current hits which could play once per day. Finally, we kept two songs in hot rotation, updated every week, which alternated on the air every other hour.
author: VodkaPundit

text: I used to work in pop radio, where I learned about music rotation. We had a huge library of older songs going back to the mid '70s, which were available to play maybe once a quarter, maybe twice a year.
